BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 14, 1918.
Major Theodore Caldwell Janeway.

The first name has been written on Hopkins' roll of honor for
lives laid down in theservice of her
country—that name is Major Theodore Caldwell Janeway. Major
Janeway, a man who stood at the
head of his profession, who had
sacrificed a gainful practice to accept the first full-time professorship in medicine ever established,
who enlisted in the service of his
country at the outbreak of war,
has laid down his life in his unceasing efforts to fit the medical
forces of the army for the tremendous stress and strain of war, in
his unflagging struggle against
the dreadful diseases that menaced men in the camps.
Of all the sacrifices that Hop-,
kins may be called upon to make,
none can be so great and so
noble as this, her first one. It
was patriotic sacrifice under
the most unfavorable conditions. There was no martial splendor,; no flare of trumpets, noflutteringbanners, to stir on thissoldier;
there was only the hideous mien
of disease, the dull monotony of
bare hospital walls, the cold, inexorable microscope of the laboratory, to stint rather than arouse
patriotic fervor. It was ideal, intelligent sacrifice. There was no
bloody battlefield with its dead and
dying, no belching cannon, no Teuton bayonet thrust, to drive him to
fight to the death; there was only
the selfless desire to serve the unwavering devotion to duty, the indefatigable will to accomplish a
task, that sapped away the life of

Major Janeway. It was the supreme sacrifice.
Our hearts go out in sympathy
to the widow and children of
Major Janeway, but we must tell
them that they are not alone in
bearing the loss of a dear one:—
the University, the medical profession, the country, and humanity have suffered equally great in
the untimely death of Major JaneWay.

A movement, originally proposed by. Dr. Ames and carried
out through the efforts of Professors Christie and Keowenhoven, of
the department of engineering of
the University, has resulted in the
establishment of a preparatory
school at Johns Hopkins for prospective aviators. The school is to
continpe for six weeks beginning
today.
The instruction to be given is
entirely voluntary on the part of
the professors giving the courses,
and there will be no changes whatever, with the possible exception
of laboratory fees. The object of
the school, according to Professor
Christie, is to give as much preliminary instruction as possible
in the subjects studied at the
ground schools at Princeton and
the Massachusetts Institute of
Technology. "The courses given
at these schools," Professor Christie said, "are extremely intensive
and difficult—between 30 and 40
per cent. of the entrants fail. Our
school is only for enlisted men and
is simply to help them out so that
our Baltimore men will be able to
make the grade. It is purely a
voluntary proposition."
The courses, as given out last
week, were as follows:
• Monday—Elements of Physics
and Mechanics, by Professor
Pfund.
Tuesday—Internal Combustion
Engines, by Professors Christie
and Dana.
Thursday—Wireless, by Professors Keowenhoven and Pullen.
Friday — Meteorology, by Professor Reed.

At a meeting of the Board of
Collegiate Studies held Tuesday,
January 8, the following regulations were adopted for the coming
year:
1. During the month of May in
each year all students in residence
must consult their advisers with
regard to the course to be taken
in thefollowing academic year. The
student must report the course selected to the Registrar before June
1. A fine of one dollaradaywillbe
levied for delay in making this report. Changes in the course may
be made by notification to the
Registrar at any time before September 25; after that date only
with the approval of the Dean.
Students who fail to attend
courses selected, or who drop
courses without the approval of
the Dean, will be marked absent
and will be subject to the regulations of the Committee on absence.
2. All undergraduate students,
new and old, must register at the
Registrar's Office on September
27, 28, or 30, 1918. A fine of one
dollar for each day of delay will
be levied against those who fail to
register before 4 P. M. on September 30, 1918.
This action was made necessary
by the fact that the College has
grown so in the last few years,
that the former method of registration and assignment to courses
is no longer adapted to our needs.

Major Theodore Caldwell Janeway.

The first name has been written on Hopkins' roll of honor for
lives laid down in theservice of her
country—that name is Major Theodore Caldwell Janeway. Major
Janeway, a man who stood at the
head of his profession, who had
sacrificed a gainful practice to accept the first full-time professorship in medicine ever established,
who enlisted in the service of his
country at the outbreak of war,
has laid down his life in his unceasing efforts to fit the medical
forces of the army for the tremendous stress and strain of war, in
his unflagging struggle against
the dreadful diseases that menaced men in the camps.
Of all the sacrifices that Hop-,
kins may be called upon to make,
none can be so great and so
noble as this, her first one. It
was patriotic sacrifice under
the most unfavorable conditions. There was no martial splendor,; no flare of trumpets, noflutteringbanners, to stir on thissoldier;
there was only the hideous mien
of disease, the dull monotony of
bare hospital walls, the cold, inexorable microscope of the laboratory, to stint rather than arouse
patriotic fervor. It was ideal, intelligent sacrifice. There was no
bloody battlefield with its dead and
dying, no belching cannon, no Teuton bayonet thrust, to drive him to
fight to the death; there was only
the selfless desire to serve the unwavering devotion to duty, the indefatigable will to accomplish a
task, that sapped away the life of

Major Janeway. It was the supreme sacrifice.
Our hearts go out in sympathy
to the widow and children of
Major Janeway, but we must tell
them that they are not alone in
bearing the loss of a dear one:—
the University, the medical profession, the country, and humanity have suffered equally great in

A movement, originally proposed by. Dr. Ames and carried
out through the efforts of Professors Christie and Keowenhoven, of
the department of engineering of
the University, has resulted in the
establishment of a preparatory
school at Johns Hopkins for prospective aviators. The school is to
continpe for six weeks beginning
today.
The instruction to be given is
entirely voluntary on the part of
the professors giving the courses,
and there will be no changes whatever, with the possible exception
of laboratory fees. The object of
the school, according to Professor
Christie, is to give as much preliminary instruction as possible
in the subjects studied at the
ground schools at Princeton and
the Massachusetts Institute of
Technology. "The courses given
at these schools," Professor Christie said, "are extremely intensive
and difficult—between 30 and 40
per cent. of the entrants fail. Our
school is only for enlisted men and
is simply to help them out so that
our Baltimore men will be able to
make the grade. It is purely a
voluntary proposition."
The courses, as given out last
week, were as follows:
• Monday—Elements of Physics
and Mechanics, by Professor
Pfund.
Tuesday—Internal Combustion
Engines, by Professors Christie
and Dana.
Thursday—Wireless, by Professors Keowenhoven and Pullen.
Friday — Meteorology, by Professor Reed.

At a meeting of the Board of
Collegiate Studies held Tuesday,
January 8, the following regulations were adopted for the coming
year:
1. During the month of May in
each year all students in residence
must consult their advisers with
regard to the course to be taken
in thefollowing academic year. The
student must report the course selected to the Registrar before June
1. A fine of one dollaradaywillbe
levied for delay in making this report. Changes in the course may
be made by notification to the
Registrar at any time before September 25; after that date only
with the approval of the Dean.
Students who fail to attend
courses selected, or who drop
courses without the approval of
the Dean, will be marked absent
and will be subject to the regulations of the Committee on absence.
2. All undergraduate students,
new and old, must register at the
Registrar's Office on September
27, 28, or 30, 1918. A fine of one
dollar for each day of delay will
be levied against those who fail to
register before 4 P. M. on September 30, 1918.
This action was made necessary
by the fact that the College has
grown so in the last few years,
that the former method of registration and assignment to courses
is no longer adapted to our needs.
